review.title: Interpolable Formulas in Equilibrium Logic and Answer Set Programming
review.abstract: Interpolation is an important property of classical and many non-classical logics that has been shown to have interesting applications in computer science and AI. Here we study the Interpolation Property for the the non-monotonic system of equilibrium logic, establishing weaker or stronger forms of interpolation depending on the precise interpretation of the inference relation. These results also yield a form of interpolation for ground logic programs under the answer sets semantics. For disjunctive logic programs we also study the property of uniform interpolation that is closely related to the concept of variable forgetting. The first-order version of equilibrium logic has analogous Interpolation properties whenever the collection of equilibrium models is (first-order) definable. Since this is the case for so-called safe programs and theories, it applies to the usual situations that arise in practical answer set programming.

sections.heading: 2.3 Interpolation in the Logic of Here-and-There
sections.text: An important and useful property of HT is the fact that it is the strongest intermediate logic (i.e. the strengthening of intuitionist logic) correctly contained in classical logic. Furthermore, it contains all other such intermediate logic. Furthermore, HT is one of exactly seven superintuitionist propositional logic that possesses the interpolation property (Maksimova, 1977; Gabbay & Maksimova, 2005). For languages without functional symbols, Ono showed that interpolation in the logic maintains QHT's quantified here and there with constant domains (Ono, 1983). Furthermore, Maksimova (1997, 1998) showed that the addition of pure equality formula, e.g. the decidable equality axiom, acquires the interpolation property to any superintuitionist logic (Gabbay & Maksimova, 2005).

sections.heading: 5. An Illustration: Interpolation for Safe Formulas
sections.text: How restrictive is the definition assumption? Is it often fulfilled in practice? In fact, non-definable classes of answer sentences do not play an essential role in mainstream answer set programming, whose language equilibrium logic covers and extends all or part of a program (see next section). The reason for this is that in answering questions existing solvers rely on grounding models that define all or part of a program before calculating the intended models or solutions. The grounding process essentially eliminates variables and reduces the original program to expressive form. In such practical cases, the collection of stable or equilibrium models will then be definable. In general, for this computational approach to work, syntactical limitations must be imposed on permissible programs or theories. The most common form of limitation is called safety. For standard types of logical programs based on rules, a rule is considered safe if every variable that appears in the rule is also free in its body.

sections.heading: 8.1 Extending the Query Language
sections.text: If we establish a uniform interpolation in ASP by applying the method of forgetting as defined by Eiter and Wang (2008), it seems clear that we cannot trivially extend the meaningfulness of the query language L. Since the method of forgetting a of E (once a has been removed) cancels non-minimal quantities, an atom b could be true in any equilibrium model of the query language, but not in any equilibrium model of forgetting. Therefore, we could have a disjunction, say a disjunction, derivable from E (as soon as a), but not from forgetting. Likewise, we cannot generally extend programs with variables in a first order setting to existential queries. On the other hand, the property of a uniform interpolation certainly applies to any L (V), even without the condition that V (b) is equally important.

sections.heading: 9. Literature and Related Work
sections.text: The interpolation theorem for classical logic is based on Craig (1957); however, it was extended by Schu � tte (1962) to intutionist logic. Maksimova (1977) characterized the superintuitionist propositional logic that interpolation possesses. A noteworthy exception is an article (Amir, 2002) that specifies some interpolation properties for paraphrasing and standard logic. By the well-known relationship between the response theorems of disjunctive programs and the extensions of corresponding standard theories, he also derives a form of interpolation for the ASP. In terms of response semantics, Amir's approach differs significantly from ours. Because it is based on an analysis of standard logic, he uses classical logic as the basis for interpolation.

sections.heading: 10. Conclusions
sections.text: We discussed two types of interpolation properties for non-monotonous inference relations and showed that these properties in turn apply to the two different inference relations that we can associate with propositional equilibrium logic. In any case, we take advantage of the fact that the collection of equilibrium models in HT logic can be defined from here and there, and that this logic has the usual form of interpolation. In many cases, one of the forms of inference investigated seems to be a suitable concept to link it to the programming of response sets, although ASP systems are generally not tailored to answering or deduction of queries. On the basis of the results of Eiter and Wang (2008) on variable forgetting in ASP, we were also able to show how the property of uniform interpolation applies to disjunctive programs and a restricted query language. It remains to consider whether |∼AS is best identified with the closed world version of inference, |∼cw, or the more open world version, |∼ow. Again, since ASP solvers do not generally implement inference engines, the difference is largely a theoretical one. In traditional logic programming, however, a query that does not belong to the language of the program is usually answered false. It also seems quite natural in an ASP context that, given a program Π and a query Q, one should consider the stable models of Π in the language L(Π)∪L(Q) even if this is a proper extension of the language of Π.10 So in general |∼cw seems a natural choice for answer set inference. On the other hand, there are contexts where answer set semantics is used in a more open world setting, for example in the setting of hybrid knowledge bases (Rosati, 2005) where non-monotonic rules are combined with ontologies formalised in description logics. For such systems a semantics in terms of equilibrium logic was provided by de Bruijn, Pearce, Polleres and Valverde (2007). Here an entailment relation in the style of |∼ow might sometimes be more appropriate.

The Interpolation property has been applied in various areas of computer science, notably in software specification (Bicarregui et al., 2001) and in the construction of formal ontologies (Lutz & Wolter, 2010).
The above proof is similar to the argument given by Lutz and Wolter (2010) for Theorem 7 of that paper, applied to TBoxes in description logics.
A stronger form of interpolation known as uniform interpolation is also important for certain applications in computer science (Konev et al., 2009).
For example it has been shown to hold for some description logics (Kontchakov et al., 2008) where such syntactic restrictions apply.

If we establish uniform interpolation in ASP using the method of forgetting, as defined by Eiter and Wang (2008), it seems clear that we cannot extend in a non-trivial way the expressive power of the query language L.
A notable exception is an article (Amir, 2002) establishing some interpolation properties for circumscription and default logic.
The interpolation theorem for classical logic is due to Craig (1957); it was extended to intutionistic logic by Schütte (1962).

metadata.abstractText: Interpolation is an important property of classical and many non-classical logics that has been shown to have interesting applications in computer science and AI. Here we study the Interpolation Property for the the non-monotonic system of equilibrium logic, establishing weaker or stronger forms of interpolation depending on the precise interpretation of the inference relation. These results also yield a form of interpolation for ground logic programs under the answer sets semantics. For disjunctive logic programs we also study the property of uniform interpolation that is closely related to the concept of variable forgetting. The first-order version of equilibrium logic has analogous Interpolation properties whenever the collection of equilibrium models is (first-order) definable. Since this is the case for so-called safe programs and theories, it applies to the usual situations that arise in practical answer set programming.
